articles.headline: Billionaires Wanted to Save the News Industry. They’re Losing a Fortune.
articles.snippet: Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times — owned by Marc Benioff, Jeff Bezos and Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong — are still losing money.
articles.abstract: Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times — owned by Marc Benioff, Jeff Bezos and Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong — are still losing money.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s an old saying about the news business: If you want to make a small fortune, start with a large one.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Taiwan’s Democracy Draws Envy and Tears for Visiting Chinese
articles.snippet: People with personal ties to China, on a tour to see Taiwan’s election up close, learned of the island’s path to democracy — messy, violent and, ultimately, inspiring.
articles.abstract: People with personal ties to China, on a tour to see Taiwan’s election up close, learned of the island’s path to democracy — messy, violent and, ultimately, inspiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Taipei train station, a Chinese human rights activist named Cuicui watched with envy as six young Taiwanese politicians campaigned for the city’s legislative seats. A decade ago, they had been involved in parallel democratic protest movements — she in China, and the politicians on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait.

articles.headline: Israeli Women Fight on Front Line in Gaza, a First
articles.snippet: After a long struggle for acceptance, Israel’s female combat soldiers are pushing new boundaries after rushing into battle on Oct. 7.
articles.abstract: After a long struggle for acceptance, Israel’s female combat soldiers are pushing new boundaries after rushing into battle on Oct. 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Capt. Amit Busi gets a chance to sleep, she does so with her boots on — and in a shared tent in an improvised Israeli military post in northern Gaza.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv

articles.headline: How Biden’s Immigration Fight Threatens His Biggest Foreign Policy Win
articles.snippet: The debate over immigration in the United States is spilling over into other parts of President Biden’s agenda, particularly the war in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The debate over immigration in the United States is spilling over into other parts of President Biden’s agenda, particularly the war in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The soaring number of people crossing into the United States from Mexico has been a political vulnerability for President Biden for the past three years, chipping away at his approval rating and opening him up to political attacks.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Erica L. Green

articles.headline: A Woman Who Shows Age Is No Barrier to Talk Show Stardom
articles.snippet: Tetsuko Kuroyanagi has been one of Japan’s best-known entertainers for seven decades. At 90, she’s still going strong.
articles.abstract: Tetsuko Kuroyanagi has been one of Japan’s best-known entertainers for seven decades. At 90, she’s still going strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pushing a walker through a television studio in central Tokyo earlier this week, Tetsuko Kuroyanagi slowly climbed three steps onto a sound stage with the help of an assistant who settled her into a creamy beige Empire armchair.

articles.headline: Apple Takes a Humble Approach to Launching Its Newest Device
articles.snippet: The Vision Pro augmented reality device goes on sale Friday. Don’t expect Apple to host a splashy event to promote it.
articles.abstract: The Vision Pro augmented reality device goes on sale Friday. Don’t expect Apple to host a splashy event to promote it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Apple released the Apple Watch in 2015, it was business as usual for a company whose iPhone updates had become cultural touchstones. Before the watch went on sale, Apple gave early versions of it to celebrities like Beyoncé, featured it in fashion publications like Vogue and streamed a splashy event on the internet trumpeting its features.

articles.headline: Bitcoin E.T.F.s Come With Risks. Here’s What You Should Know.
articles.snippet: Federal regulators have made it easier for everyday investors to buy funds that track the price of Bitcoin, using traditional brokerage accounts. Most financial advisers remain skeptical.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators have made it easier for everyday investors to buy funds that track the price of Bitcoin, using traditional brokerage accounts. Most financial advisers remain skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a dozen new investments funds that hold Bitcoin began trading last week, making it easier for anyone with a basic brokerage account to buy a slice of the digital currency.
